content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very easy ok but interesting problem. I think this one can't be a clash it takes me a lot more than 15 minutes to solve it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting trivia, simple but not too trivial. The source links are a good idea.
Agreed that it is best for this problem to not be a clash. It's a pretty good simple puzzle :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Funny, based on general knowledge, very clear, a lot of validation tests.

The main difficulty for a clash is to write data in the vectors. Add quotes manually is boring. I wrote a split function, but any mistake in it coud be frustrating in a clash.
Maybe the 4 alphabets could be provided in input  (without coma) ?

For the problem itself, it's solved with 8 lines of easy C++.

It's fun. :-)

I disagree that this would work better as a clash, and I think it would get banned by feedback very quickly. Unless the 4 alphabets are provided as inputs with a stub, it would be very irritating to be racing to copy and paste a bunch of text under time pressure.

I also don't think that short & concise solutions should disqualify this from being a puzzle. It's also easy, but that's what easy puzzles are supposed to be.

EDIT:
Forgot to mention: Validators 5 and 9 are problematic. If I'm correct in assuming the significance of tests 10 and 11 is in testing the solution for words that appear in more than one phonetic alphabet, then there is a problem with the words "Quebec" and "Charlie" being included in validator 5 and validator 9, respectively.

Yea I'm going to have to agree with others here, this one should probably be a clash. It can be solved in 2 lines (without including the alphabets) with a language like ruby and the hardest part about this was just setting up all the alphabets.
ALL: I put some tags in but feel free to comment if you have better ideas :)

I appreciate the below comments but I feel sure that if I put this as a Clash, the feedback would be "Too hard for a clash".

So I'm gonna go ahead and submit as a Classic and see what happens.
I think this one could definitively be a clash.
This was fun.   My C# solution went to line 18 compared to your 100.  This would make an interesting shortest mode clash too.

If anyone has ideas for tags, please tell me.
(Is there a list of tags I can look thru for inspiration?)

Here's the list of tags:
https://chadok.info/codingame/tags_list.html

Cool.

Yeah, definitely I need to optimize.

I'm generally inspired to create puzzles only when I don't immediately know how to solve them, so definitely a learning experience.  

Share your code in direct message in forum with me if you feel comfortable doing that.

How are y'all doing this so easily?
Teach me!

Thanks.

I swapped test to validator and validator to test on #5 and #8 and #9.

I also added 2 more test/validator sets at the end to test explicitly for Quebec (which I hadn't noticed repeated, so definitely thanks for pointing that out).

How is it now?

And I put in a double tricky test/validator of "Quebec Charlie"
It looks good! I like the Quebec Charlie validator, it's very evil (in a good way).
Yes, exactly.  I like how by coincidence it becomes “capture queen” — an evil sounding phrase

I work in C++ but i think the idea can be transposed to many langages.
The idea is to have your 4 versions saved as vectors/arrays. The index of the first letter of a word in the alphabet will also be the index of the word in the vector/array of any version. you just have to find which version to evolve to :)
I mean that's basically how I did it, but that definitely was not easy coding for me.
I left the IDE and didn't save it anywhere.  If I have a moment, I will re-write it and share.
